Prerequisite: Two courses from 120, 140 series (or equivalent).

FREN 170.description:
Theory and practice of translation for various purposes including literary, scientific, and professional ones. Comparative stylistics of English and French.

Prerequisite: FREN 110 (or equivalent).

FREN 180.description:
Individual work by arrangement.

Prerequisite: Upper division standing in French (or equivalent preparation with grade of "B") and instructor consent.

FREN 202.courseName: Seminar in French/Francophone Civilizations and Culture
FREN 202.description: Research projects exploring the character of France, analysis of French culture and institutions or the appreciation of the cultural richness and diversity of Francophone areas throughout the world, highlighting differences among French-speaking peoples and countries.

FREN 210.courseName: Instructional Resources for the Teaching of French Language and Culture
FREN 210.description:
Provides instruction in recent resources developed for the teaching of French as a second language. Materials (films, audiotapes, textbooks and resources on the Internet) are selected and evaluated according to the National Standards for Foreign Language Teaching.

Notes: Alternate years, or on demand.

FREN 240.description: Majors works in Francophone literature from Quebec, Western Africa, Maghreb, West Indies and other Francophone countries. Analysis and comparison of poetry, plays and novels in relation to French metropolitan literature. Special attention to social and political issues. May be repeated for credit when course content changes.

FREN 250.description:
Detailed study of selected French novels. May be repeated for credit when course content changes.

Notes: Every fourth year, or on demand.

FREN 260.description:
Study in depth of selected works of the French theatre. May be repeated for credit when course content changes.

Notes: Every fourth year, or on demand.

FREN 298.description:
Advanced individual research and projects.

Prerequisite: Instructor consent.

FREN 299.description: Prerequisite: Admission to candidacy for the MA degree or advisor consent.

FORL 025.courseName: World Cultures Through Literature and Cinema
FORL 025.description: Introduction to contemporary non-English speaking cultures taught online in English; Specialized modules highlight cultural features, interactions, and contributions of culture groups associated with five world languages (initially Chinese, French, German, Japanese, Spanish) examined through literature and films. Fulfills GE C1/C2

FORL 096A.description: This course is designed for heritage or non-native speakers of the Assyrian language with limited speaking fluency and no writing or reading skills. Starting with the alphabet, students will learn reading and writing skills, and acquire elementary oral communication. (Special Session only).

FORL 100W.description:
Advanced composition with practice in research and development of writing skills using a variety of literary and cultural concepts. GE Area: Z

Prerequisite: A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); Completion of core GE, satisfaction of Writing Skills Test and upper division standing.

Note: Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment requirement (GWAR).

FORL 180.courseName: Individual Studies in World Languages and Literatures
FORL 180.description:
FORL 180 is designed for individual studies in languages taught at SJSU that are not part of a major or minor program, such as Arabic, Hebrew, Persian/Farsi or Vietnamese.

Prerequisite: Upper division standing, instructor approval

FORL 200.description:
Techniques of writing research papers and theses. Includes bibliographical sources and style sheets. Comprehensive study of literary genres and techniques for critique of these genres. Emphasis on organization of materials.

Note: This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master's program.

FORL 205.description:
An introduction to the development of the Romance languages from Vulgar Latin: phonology, morphology, syntax, lexical growth; emergence of dialects. Preparatory to historical linguistics of any Romance language.

Prerequisite: Fundamental knowledge of Latin and a bachelor's degree (or equivalent) in at least one Romance language.

GERM 001B.description:

GERM 025B.description:
Introduction of complex grammatical features, continued expansion of vocabulary and communication skills in the context of culture. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite: Three semesters of college German or equivalent.

GERM 101A.description:
Readings, oral discussion, syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college German (or equivalent).

GERM 101B.description:
Readings, oral discussion, syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college German (or equivalent).

GERM 102A.description:
Development of society, civilization and culture in German-speaking countries until 1871, including aspects of geography, political and intellectual history, fine art and cultural anthropology.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college German (or equivalent).

GERM 102B.description:
Development of society, civilization and culture in German-speaking countries from 1871 to the present, including aspects of geography, political and intellectual history, fine art and cultural anthropology.

Individual work by arrangement.

Developing speaking skills.

Readings, grammar, discussion and composition.

ITAL 001B.description:

Alternate to Ital 1A and Ital 1B. Student sets own rate of progress. May be repeated for a 5 unit maximum.

Prerequisite: 5 units of ITAL 1A, ITAL 1X (or equivalent).

ITAL 002.description:
Sentence structure and idiomatic usage in compositions, translations and simple essays.

Prerequisite: 2 semesters of college Italian (or equivalent).

Readings, discussion, syntax and composition. When content changes may be repeated.

Readings, discussion, syntax and composition. When content changes may be repeated.

Culture and civilization of Italy. Dante, Manzoni, Moravia, Quasimodo, Montale, etc. When content changes may be repeated.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Italian (or equivalent).

JPN 001A.description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture. GE Area: C2

JPN 001B.description:
Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite:  JPN 001A (or equivalent).

Continuation of JPN 001B. Preparation for advanced courses in the language. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite: One Year of college-level Japanese (or equivalent or SJSU placement exam).

JPN 025B.description:
Continuation of JPN 025A. Preparation for advanced courses in the language. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite: Three semesters of college Japanese (or equivalent).

JPN 101A.description:
Readings, oral discussion, study of syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Japanese (or equivalent).

JPN 101B.description:
Readings, oral discussion, study of syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Japanese (or equivalent).

JPN 101C.description:
This course focuses on politeness aspects of Japanese language that appear in L19, 20, and 23 of Genki textbook II and heightens conversational competence to intermediate high in ACTFL through project works.

Prerequisite: JPN 025B

JPN 102.description:
History, geography, fine art and daily life of Japan. May be repeated when content changes.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Japanese (or equivalent).

JPN 103.description:
Ideographs and Kana-syllabaries in their historical contexts-meaning, imagery, socio-anthropological backgrounds, formation and use of modern Japanese. Studio practice.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent.

JPN 105.description:
Examination of language that appears in Japanese media such as newspapers, Internet news, and TV news to enhance four language skills (listening, reading, speaking and writing) to advanced level.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent

JPN 107.description:
Advanced Japanese course for specific (business) purposes. It will acquaint students with practical vocabulary, a wide range of language structures, business manners, and business customs for developing communication skills useful in conducting business in Japanese.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent.

JPN 110.description:
Structural analysis of Japanese from historical as well as descriptive perspectives and its application to distinct Japanese social and communicative behaviors.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent.

JPN 120.description:
Examination of Modern Japanese Manga Literature and Light novels and their translation to heighten learners reading and translation skills.

Prerequisite: 101C or equivalent

JPN 130.description:
Readings from contemporary texts (including scholarly essays, newspapers and narrative) on various aspects of Japanese culture.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent.

JPN 140.description:
Interpretation of Japanese drama and lyrics from Showa to the present to foster advanced level of Japanese language competence. Analysis of stylistic features, Japanese people and society's socio-cultural values and their historical backgrounds.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent

JPN 150.description:
Examination of Japanese narratives (folk tales) and life stories that represent Japanese society and archetype of Japanese people's psychology.

Prerequisite: JPN 101C or equivalent

JPN 180.description:
Individual work by arrangement.

Prerequisite: 11 units of upper division Japanese (or equivalent with grade of "B") and instructor consent.

LATN 001A.description:
Latin grammar, syntax and readings.

LATN 001B.description:
Latin grammar, syntax and readings.

PERS 001A.courseName: Elementary Persian Culture and Language I
PERS 001A.description: An elementary level course, designed for students with no or little previous knowledge of Persian language and meant to be an introduction to Persian cultures.

PERS 001B.description:
This course is a continuation of PERS 96A (PERS 1A) and is designed for students who have some basic knowledge of Persian through self-training, travel, or have completed a course at an academic institution. Emphasis is placed in further developing the students' knowledge of culture and language and across the Persian-speaking world. (Special Session only).

Prerequisite: PERS 096A or instructor consent.

PERS 025A.description:
This course is designed for students with some previous knowledge of Persian, either from classroom or as a heritage speaker. Various language activities such as reading, writing, and, listening comprehension will be offered through the introduction of classical Persian poetry.

Prerequisite: Instructor Consent

PERS 025B.description:
This course is a continuation of PERS 25A and is designed for students with previous knowledge of Persian, either from classroom or as a heritage speaker. Various language activities such as reading, writing, and, listening comprehension will be introduced while surveying the history and culture of the Persian speaking world across time and place, with a focus on Iran, from its roots in antiquity to the modern day, advancing students' knowledge of Persian language and culture. Themes include the survey of history, socio-political systems, and textual and visual cultural traditions of the Persian society, which have made this culture a unique one for centuries. This course is conducted in Persian while the reading assignments are in both English and Persian.

Prerequisite: PERS 25A or instructor consent.

PORT 001A.description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.

PORT 001B.description:
Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.

Prerequisite: PORT 001A (or equivalent).

PORT 001X.description: Alternate to Port 1A and Port 1B. Student sets own rate of progress. May be repeated for a 5 unit maximum.

PORT 001Y.description:
Alternate to Port 1A and Port 1B. Student sets own rate of progress. May be repeated for a 5 unit maximum.

PORT 020B.description:

PORT 020X.description:
Alternate to Port 20A. Student sets own rate of progress. May be repeated for a 3 unit maximum.

Prerequisite: 2 semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

PORT 020Y.description:
Alternate to Port 20B. Student sets own rate of progress. May be repeated for a 3  unit maximum.

Prerequisite: 3 semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

PORT 101A.description:
Reading, discussion, morphology, syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

PORT 101B.description:
Reading, discussion, morphology, syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

PORT 102A.description:
Portuguese 102A provides students with a variety of aspects of the culture and civilization including geography, history, literature, customs, music, sports, media etc. of the different countries of the Portuguese Speaking world (Portugal, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Sao Tome and Principe, Angola, Mozambique, and East Timor.

Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit with content changes.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

PORT 102B.description:
History, geography, fine art and daily life in Brazil.

Prerequisite: Upper division standing

PORT 180.description:
By arrangement.

Prerequisite: Upper division standing in Portuguese (or equivalent) and instructor consent.

SPAN 001A.description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture. GE Area: C2

SPAN 001B.description:
Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite: SPAN 001A (or equivalent).

SPAN 003.description:
Spanish 003 is a Special Topics course focused on the practical application of basic Spanish in a number of professional fields such as Health Care, Social Services, Hospitality Management, and Law Enforcement.

Repeatable for credit when content changes.

Prerequisite: 9 units of college Spanish (or equivalent).

Notes: Not accepted as preparation for advanced courses. Native speakers see General Information section.

SPAN 004A.description: An Internet-based or on-site course in practical Spanish for use in a variety of professional and everyday activities. For beginners and those who need to improve conversational skills. May be repeated for 6 unit maximum.

SPAN 004B.description:
An Internet-based or on-site course course in practical Spanish for use in a variety of professional and everyday activities. A continuation of SPAN 004A for those who need to improve communication skills. May be repeated for 6 unit maximum.

Notes: No credit toward Spanish major.

SPAN 020A.description:
Focus on written Spanish. Study of grammar and orthography and development of reading and writing skills. For students whose first or home language is Spanish.

Prerequisite: Knowledge of spoken Spanish and instructor consent.

SPAN 020B.description:
Continuation of Span 020A. For students whose first or home language is Spanish. Focus on development of reading and writing skills.

Prerequisite: SPAN 020A or instructor consent.

SPAN 025A.description:
Continuation of Span 001B. Preparation for advanced courses in the language. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite: One Year of college-level Spanish (or equivalent or SJSU Placement Exam).

SPAN 025B.description:
Continuation of Span 025A. Preparation for advanced courses in the language. GE Area: C2

Prerequisite: Three semesters of college Spanish (or equivalent).

SPAN 101A.description:
Readings, oral discussion, syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semester of college Spanish (or equivalent).

SPAN 101B.description:
Readings, oral discussion, syntax and composition.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Spanish (or equivalent).

SPAN 102A.description:
History, geography, fine art and daily life of Spain.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Spanish (or equivalent).

SPAN 102B.description:
History, geography, fine art and daily life of Hispanic America. GE Area: V

Prerequisite: Passage of the Writing Skills Test (WST) or ENGL/LLD 100A with a C or better (C- not accepted), completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.

Notes: Offered in Spanish or English in alternate semesters. Spanish majors and minors must register for Spanish version.

SPAN 105.description:
Contrastive analysis of Spanish and English sound systems and application to pronunciation. Language laboratory.

Prerequisite: Four semesters of college Spanish (or equivalent).

SPAN 110.description:
Structural analysis. Comparison of morphological and syntactical patterns of English and Spanish.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B (or equivalent).

SPAN 111.description:
Development of skills for group discussion, dialogue and individual oral presentations on topics pertaining to everyday life, the professions, social problems and the arts. May be repeated once for credit, but only 3 units apply to major.


Prerequisite: 4 semesters of college Spanish or advisor consent.

Notes: Native speakers see General Information section.

SPAN 115.courseName: Introduction to Literary Studies in Spanish
SPAN 115.description:
Introduction to literary studies in Spanish with readings from Spain and Spanish America. Overview of genres and fundamental concepts of criticism.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B or instructor consent.

SPAN 120A.description:
Notable works from beginning to present.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B, SPAN 102A or SPAN 102B (or equivalent).

SPAN 120B.description:
Notable works from beginning to present.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B, SPAN 102A or SPAN 102B (or equivalent).

SPAN 132.courseName: Special Topics in Spanish for Careers
SPAN 132.description:
Course will focus on the use of the Spanish language for various professions, and examines in depth selected topics in regard to Spanish in the professional world.

Course repeatable when content varies.

Prerequisite: Two years of Spanish or instructor consent.

SPAN 140A.description:
Notable works from beginning to present.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B, SPAN 102A and SPAN 102B (or equivalent).

SPAN 140B.description:
Notable works from beginning to present.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B, SPAN 102A and SPAN 102B (or equivalent).

SPAN 160A.description:
Cultural phenomena, both historical and contemporary, of Spanish-speaking countries. Repeatable when topic changes for up to 8 units.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B (or equivalent).

SPAN 160B.description:
Spanish as spoken in diverse Hispanic cultures. May be repeated for credit when content changes.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B (or equivalent).

SPAN 160C.description:
Outstanding authors or movements of Spain and Latin America.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B (or equivalent).

SPAN 170.description:
Theory and practice of translation for various purposes including literary, scientific, and professional ones. Comparative stylistics of English and Spanish.

Prerequisite: SPAN 101B.

SPAN 180.description:
Individual work by arrangement.

Prerequisite: Upper division standing in Spanish (or equivalent with grade of "B") and instructor consent.

SPAN 201.description: Analysis of the evolving patterns of syntax and idiomatic construction in the Spanish language of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. May be repeated for credit when content changes.

SPAN 202.courseName: Seminar in Hispanic Civilization and Culture
SPAN 202.description: A comprehensive study of one or more Spanish-speaking countries. A: Andean countries (Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia). B: Caribbean (Cuba, Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico and Caribbean coasts of Venezuela, Colombia and the nations of Central America). C: Mexico. D: River Plate Region (Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay). E: Spain. May be repeated for credit when course content changes.

SPAN 210.description:
Analysis of the style and structure of medieval Spanish through selected readings. A fundamental knowledge of Latin is required.

Notes: Alternate years, or on demand.

SPAN 220.description: An inquiry into the growth of the Spanish language in Spain and Latin America from the twelfth century to modern times.

SPAN 225.description:
Regional, social, historical, generational dialects that shape Spanish. Research involves readings on dialectology and sociolinguistics, learning to identify characteristics of Spanish dialects and exploring the implications of language contact, linguistic borrowing and code-switching.

Prerequisite: Graduate standing or instructor consent.

SPAN 250.courseName: Seminar in the Siglo de Oro
SPAN 250.description: The works of Cervantes, principal dramatists of the Comedia and other significant authors of the Golden Age. May be repeated for credit when content changes.

SPAN 260.courseName: Seminar in "Modernismo" and the Generation of '98
SPAN 260.description: A: Origin and development of the poetry and prose of the Modernista movement in Latin America. B: Examination of the spiritual and intellectual crisis created in Spain by the 1898 Spanish-American War. Representative works of Unamuno, Baroja, Azorin, Valle-Inclan and Antonio Machado. May be repeated for credit when content changes.

SPAN 270.courseName: Seminar in Contemporary Literature of Spain and Spanish America
SPAN 270.description: In-depth study of representative Latin American and Spanish authors of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. May be repeated for credit when content changes.

SPAN 280.courseName: Seminar in Romanticism in Spain and Spanish America
SPAN 280.description: Philosophical and artistic aspects of the movement, studied through representative Latin American or Spanish works in all literary genres. Focus will alternate each time the course is offered. May be repeated for credit when content changes.

SPAN 298.description:
Advanced individual research and projects.

Prerequisite: Instructor consent.

SPAN 299.description: Prerequisite: Admission to candidacy for the MA degree and advisor consent.

VIET 001A.description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.

VIET 001B.description:
Continuation of Viet 1A. Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.

Prerequisite: VIET 1A or equivalent.

VIET 020A.description:
Designed for Vietnamese speakers wishing to learn to read and write in Vietnamese.  Focus on teaching the five accents, the twelve vowels, basic grammar structures and translation from English to Vietnamese.

Prerequisite: Knowledge of spoken Vietnamese and instructor consent.

VIET 020B.description: Continuation of Viet 20A. Readings in cultural history and translation of materials to further develop literacy in heritage speakers of Vietnamese.
